factoid: At dusk, Prince Andrew and Pierre drove up to the front entrance of the house at Bald Hills.
While approaching the house, Prince Andrew smiled and drew Pierre’s attention to a commotion at the back porch.
A woman bent with age, carrying a wallet on her back, and a short long‑haired young man in a black garment rushed back to the gate when they saw the carriage driving up.
Two women ran out after them, and all four looked round at the carriage before running in dismay up the steps of the back porch.
Prince Andrew said that those people were Mary’s "God’s folk".
Prince Andrew said that the pilgrims had mistaken them for his father and that Mary disobeys him by receiving the pilgrims even though he orders them to be driven away.
Pierre asked what "God's folk" were.
Prince Andrew had no time to answer; servants came out to meet them; he asked where the old prince was and whether he was expected back soon.
The old prince had gone to town and was expected back any minute.
Prince Andrew led Pierre to his own apartments, which were always kept in perfect order and readiness for him in his father’s house; Prince Andrew himself went to the nursery.
Prince Andrew told Pierre that they should go and see his sister when he returned.

Prince Andrew said he had not found his sister yet, that she was hiding now, sitting with her "God's folk"; he said it would serve her right, she would be confused, but Pierre would see her "God's folk"; he said it was very curious.
Pierre asked again what "God's folk" were.
Prince Andrew told Pierre to come and see for himself.
Princess Mary was disconcerted and red patches appeared on her face when they went in.
In Princess Mary’s snug room, a young lad with a long nose and long hair, wearing a monk’s cassock, sat on the sofa beside her, behind a samovar.
Near them, in an armchair, sat a thin shriveled old woman with a meek expression on her childlike face.
Princess Mary said to Andrew, "why didn’t you warn me?" with mild reproach, standing before her pilgrims like a hen before her chickens.
Princess Mary said to Pierre, "Charmée de vous voir. Je suis très contente de vous voir," as he kissed her hand.
Princess Mary had known Pierre as a child.
Princess Mary’s favorable disposition toward Pierre was due to his friendship with Andrew, his misfortune with his wife, and his kindly simple face.
Princess Mary looked at Pierre with her beautiful radiant eyes and seemed to say, "I like you very much, but please don’t laugh at my people."
After exchanging greetings, Princess Mary and Pierre sat down.
Prince Andrew said, "Ah, and Ivánushka is here too!" while glancing with a smile at the young pilgrim.
Princess Mary said "Andrew!" imploringly.
Prince Andrew told Pierre, "Il faut que vous sachiez que c’est une femme."
Princess Mary repeated, "Andrew, au nom de Dieu!".
It was evident that Prince Andrew’s ironical tone toward the pilgrims and Princess Mary’s helpless attempts to protect them were their customary long‑established relations on the matter.
Prince Andrew said, "Mais, ma bonne amie, vous devriez au contraire m’être reconnaissante de ce que j’explique à Pierre votre intimité avec ce jeune homme."
Pierre said "Really?" while gazing over his spectacles with curiosity and seriousness into Ivánushka’s face.
Ivánushka looked round at them all with crafty eyes when she saw that she was being spoken about.
